input:
30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend (Free Guide)

Covers Software 1.0 (Analysis & Data Pipelines), Software 2.0 (ML), Software 3.0 (Prompt Engineering, RAG, AI Agents, Fine-tuning)
writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose & Audience
Purpose: Educate and promote a free guide ("30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend"). Show the range of project types possible in AI today and hint at the structure of the guide.
Target Audience: Aspiring AI builders, technical tinkerers, beginners-to-intermediates, and solo founders interested in practical AI projects.

Step 2: Wireframe
[Engaging 1-2 line hook (above the fold on LinkedIn)]
[Short intro about the post and the free guide]
[3 project categories: Software 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0, each with a sentence on scope]
[Link to download/free guide access]
[CTA: single focused question]

Step 3: The Meat
- Briefly introduce the free guide. Emphasize that it covers a spectrum: Software 1.0 (data analysis, pipelines), Software 2.0 (ML projects), Software 3.0 (prompt engineering, RAG, agents, fine-tuning).
- Highlight that all projects are practical and can be done in a weekend.
- Mention it's designed for those who want to build and learn by doing.

Step 4: CTA
What type of AI project are you most excited to try: data analysis, ML, or 3.0 (prompting/agents)?

Step 5: Hook Directions & Final Hook
Step 5A: Brainstorm Hook Directions
- [List Post/Numbers] "30 AI projects you can build this weekend (with zero cost)"
- [Problem/Solution] "Stuck staring at AI tutorials? Here are 30 hands-on projects you can finish in a weekend."
- [Beginner-to-Expert Clarity] "From classic data pipelines to AI agents — all in one free weekend guide."
- [Trend/Levels] "Software 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0: 30 real projects to help you master every phase of AI."
- [User’s own phrasing] "30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend (Free Guide)"
Step 5B: Add Short Notes
- [List Post/Numbers] Emphasizes volume and speed, appeals to builder mindset.
- [Problem/Solution] Overcomes analysis paralysis, positions guide as actionable.
- [Beginner-to-Expert Clarity] Addresses confusion with AI project types, clarifies scope.
- [Trend/Levels] Hooks with levels/tiers; appeals to those wanting structured growth.
- [User’s own phrasing] Utilitarian, clear but less punchy than some options.
Step 5C: Pick & Write Final Hook
[Trend/Levels] “Software 1.0, 2.0, 3.0: 30 practical AI projects you can build this weekend (free guide)”

Step 6: Draft Full Post
Software 1.0, 2.0, 3.0: 30 practical AI projects you can build this weekend (free guide)

Overwhelmed by the sheer number of AI tools out there? I put together a free resource with 30 hands-on projects you can actually build—no fluff:

• Software 1.0: Classic data analysis and automation projects (think data pipelines, reporting dashboards).
• Software 2.0: Core machine learning (training models, basic predictors, simple classifiers).
• Software 3.0: All things LLM—prompt engineering, RAG workflows, building AI agents, even trying your hand at fine-tuning.

Every project is designed to be practical, approachable, and finishable in a weekend.

Grab the free guide here: [link]

Which type of AI project are you most excited to try: classic analysis, machine learning, or agents/prompts?

Step 7: Review for Style, Voice, Flow
- No more than one em dash — passed.
- Hook is clear and about the “levels”/types (good fit for audience).
- Body outlines the three software “eras” in simple language.
- CTA is one focused question.
- Scannable and friendly.

Step 8: Final Post
final_post:
